values.alignmentText: Vancouver’s tech corridor—anchored by Microsoft, Amazon, SAP, and a dense startup scene in Gastown and Mount Pleasant—keeps senior .NET architects in demand, and Pacific time overlap lets Trey mix local contracts with West Coast U.S. clients.
Marine breezes normally keep PM2.5 near the teens, yet each late summer the family monitors wildfire smoke drifting down the Fraser Valley before planning playground time.
Kitsilano, Jericho, and Spanish Banks are spotless and transit-accessible, yet chilly Pacific water and occasional E. coli advisories keep swims short.
Stores like Rain City Games, Dicey Business, and Vancouver’s D&D Adventurers League keep English-friendly tables open for campaigns and prototype nights.
Strong community-center programming, seawall cycling, and the Playland/Science World combo give the kids abundant options despite long rainy spells.
Once enrolled, provincial fee reductions and Canada Child Benefit top-ups keep monthly costs reasonable for middle-income families.
Work-permit holders with SINs qualify for subsidies, but verifying residency and tax status can delay reimbursements in the first year.
Climbing gyms, mountain biking, and board-game cafés are plentiful, giving Trey and Sarah four-season outlets even when weather keeps everyone indoors.
Neighbors are polite but the “Vancouver freeze” is real, so we plan to build friendships through school councils, climbing gyms, and gaming meetups.
Metro Vancouver’s rents, daycare fees, and grocery prices consistently rank among Canada’s highest, so even with tech incomes we model budgets carefully before committing to leases.
Vancouver School Board offers robust French immersion and STEM mini-schools, though we may need to lottery in early for the best programs.
Urban tree canopies, seawall greenways, and aggressive waste-diversion targets make day-to-day life feel clean, with only port traffic and construction dust creating occasional hotspots.
September stays pleasant around 12–18 °C (54–64 °F), but by late October Pacific storms bring long wet weeks that push weekend plans indoors.
EA Vancouver, The Coalition, Relic, Blackbird Interactive, and a deep mobile sector create a steady ladder of roles if Trey needs salaried stability.

Sea-level rise projections for False Creek and more frequent wildfire smoke give the family equal parts manageable and disruptive risk, pushing us to favor higher-elevation neighborhoods and renter’s insurance.
B.C.’s MSP covers hospital and pediatric care, yet family doctors are scarce, so we expect to rely on nurse practitioners and urgent-care clinics.
Newcomers face a three-month MSP wait and must show work permits, so we budget for interim private insurance while filing paperwork.
Family-friendly rentals under 3,000 CAD are scarce, pushing us toward Burnaby or New Westminster condos unless we secure co-op housing.
English dominates civic life, with Cantonese and Mandarin prevalent in services—handy for multicultural exposure without language barriers.
Davie Village, trans-inclusive healthcare, and Pride’s citywide support signal that queer and poly-friendly values are openly embraced.
B.C.’s 17.40 CAD minimum wage climbs annually with inflation, yet housing costs outpace it, so entry-level earners still need roommates or supplements.
Snow-capped Coast Mountains, Stanley Park’s old-growth remnants, and ferry access to the Gulf Islands put bucket-list scenery within an hour of home.
Daily life is calm, yet Cascadia megathrust planning, atmospheric river floods, and landslide-prone North Shore slopes mean we maintain earthquake kits and renters insurance.
SkyTrain and SeaBus rides lead straight to Lynn Canyon, Grouse Mountain, and the North Shore trails, letting Trey and Sarah slot hikes into regular weekends.
A midsized live-music circuit—from the Commodore Ballroom to Fortune Sound—offers variety, but liquor curfews and zoning caps make late nights quieter than Seattle.
Craft breweries and cocktail lounges anchor evening plans, yet few venues run past 1 a.m., suiting parents who prefer earlier wrap-ups.
DigiBC, Vancouver Game Dev, and events at Vancouver Film School host monthly mixers, jams, and mentorship nights that welcome newcomers.
From EA’s Burnaby campus to indie standouts like Klei, East Side Games, and Hinterland, Vancouver packs AAA and boutique studios within a 30-minute commute.
Creative BC tax credits, Canada Media Fund, and access to veteran talent make studio launches feasible, though high burn rates demand disciplined budgeting.
Downtown runs at a big-city tempo, but neighborhood high streets and easy access to beaches create natural pauses that help Sarah downshift.
Polyamory-friendly meetups, legal aid workshops, and inclusive housing co-ops make it socially safe to be out, even if legal structures remain monogamy-centric.
$10-a-Day conversions are rolling out, but waitlists in Kitsilano and East Van stretch 12–18 months, so we join co-op daycares early.
City Hall leans left on housing, climate, and harm reduction, aligning with the family’s progressive politics despite occasional provincial pushback.
SkyTrain, RapidBus, and the SeaBus keep the core car-optional, yet coverage thins east of Coquitlam and late-night service is limited for parents heading home from events.
Co-working hubs like WeWork Marine Gateway and L’Atelier plus PST overlap with Seattle and California make hybrid schedules normal in tech.
Rails shops like Clio, Later, and Bench keep a steady trickle of roles, but Sarah may supplement with remote U.S. clients when local openings slow.
Violent crime stays low, but property theft and visible opioid crises downtown mean we stay alert around the Granville and East Hastings corridors.
Summer sea temperatures peak around 17 °C (63 °F), which is swimmable only with brief dips or wetsuits, so full beach days revolve around sand play.
Mild temperatures line up with Sarah’s preferences, but months of cold rain from November through March have us stockpiling waterproof gear and backup indoor plans.
March and April hover around 6–14 °C (43–57 °F) with steady drizzle, so playground days alternate with Science World and community centers until May dries out.
Typical July highs sit near 22–24 °C (72–75 °F) with low humidity, letting the kids bike the seawall, while brief heat domes require shaded parks and portable AC.
Senior engineers pull 140k–170k CAD plus stock at Amazon, Microsoft, and local unicorns, supporting a middle-class lifestyle if we rein in housing spend.
Weekends lean into Grouse gondola hikes, Granville Island markets, and rainy-day museum passes, keeping the kids engaged year-round.
Schools operate roughly 8:55–3:00, and tech teams often start 9:30 to sync with Toronto or Seattle, giving us time for school drop-off before stand-up.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries

values.alignmentText: The blend of seawall cycling, mountain vistas, and progressive civic culture gives the family a rare mix of adventure and shared values.
Winters hover near 1–7 °C (34–45 °F) with damp chill and occasional snowfall that freezes streets, so we budget for rain gear more than heavy parkas.

Every season brings common extremes, so we rely on specialized clothing, cooling, or heating solutions to stay comfortable. Seasonal Weather at 6/10 and Natural Disasters at 4/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for seasonal extremes & variability.

Deep winter gloom lasts several weeks, so we plan strict routines, supplements, and possible getaways to maintain morale. Seasonal Weather at 6/10 and Environment at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for seasonal sunlight hours.

Roughly half the year is wonderful, half demands planning around heat, cold, or rain to enjoy time outside. Seasonal Weather at 6/10 and Environment at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for pleasant weather windows.

Basic needs are met but savings and extracurriculars are hard to sustain without extra support or side work. Minimum Wage at 6/10, Housing Situation at 3/10, and Childcare Support (Citizens) at 8/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for quality of life – lower-income tier.

Housing and childcare strain the budget, limiting savings and discretionary spending most months. Typical Software Salaries at 7/10, Housing Situation at 3/10, and Work-Life Balance at 7/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for quality of life – middle-income tier.

Premium experiences exist but feel overpriced, shallow, or socially frowned upon. Housing Situation at 3/10, Private Education at 5/10, and Family Life at 8/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for quality of life – higher-income tier.

values.key: Spacious Housing Benchmark (2k sq ft Rent)
values.alignmentText: Spacious rentals are rare; we likely settle for smaller homes or relocate to a different metro. Housing Situation at 3/10 and Cost of Living (Optional) at 3/10 steer the family toward a challenging outlook for spacious housing benchmark (2k sq ft rent).

Intentional communities exist but are limited in size or geared toward niche demographics. Community Vibes at 6/10, Meetups & Communities at 8/10, and Family Life at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for community living opportunities.

Friendliness varies by neighborhood; we can cultivate ties but must invest time and select communities carefully. Community Vibes at 6/10, Meetups & Communities at 8/10, and Common Hobbies at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for friendliness & neighborliness index.

Interactions can be efficient yet emotionally flat; kindness takes effort to elicit. Community Vibes at 6/10, Nightlife Culture at 6/10, and Common Hobbies at 8/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for surface interaction norms.

Relationships deepen steadily with consistent effort; vulnerability is appreciated though not automatic. Community Vibes at 6/10, Meetups & Communities at 8/10, and What Is Intriguing at 9/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for depth-seeking social norms.

Expect to navigate varied norms—crowded spaces or warm cultures may lean into closer contact. Community Vibes at 6/10, Sex (Attitudes) at 8/10, and View of self at 7/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for personal boundary & bubble norms.

Openness is usually welcomed though some contexts expect diplomacy and softening of hard truths. Progressivism at 8/10, What Is Intriguing at 9/10, and Trust in Government at 7/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for moral, honesty & openness expectations.

Most encounters are considerate though occasional missteps require direct communication. Sex (Attitudes) at 8/10, LGBTQ+ Attitudes at 9/10, and Nightlife Culture at 6/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for flirting boundaries & consent culture.

Supportive subcultures exist and mainstream spaces remain tolerant if discreet. Polyamory at 8/10, Sex (Attitudes) at 8/10, and Community Vibes at 6/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for monogamy vs. non-monogamy acceptance.

Attitudes split; open discussion is fine in urban enclaves yet frowned upon elsewhere. Sex (Attitudes) at 8/10, Nightlife & Music at 6/10, and Community Vibes at 6/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for promiscuity attitudes.

Acceptance exists within progressive scenes and is tolerated publicly with respectful curiosity. Polyamory at 8/10, Community Vibes at 6/10, and LGBTQ+ Attitudes at 9/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for group & multi-partner relationship attitudes.

We occasionally experience closer contact than preferred but can steer interactions politely. Community Vibes at 6/10, Sex (Attitudes) at 8/10, and Nightlife Culture at 6/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for personal space & touch norms.

Laws are moderate; we occasionally encounter firearms but rarely feel threatened. Safety & Crime at 6/10, State Ideology at 7/10, and Political System at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for firearm laws & ownership culture.

Possession laws are moderate though some substances still carry steep fines. Progressivism at 8/10, Political System at 8/10, and Safety & Crime at 6/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for controlled substance policies.

Approach varies by district; we track neighborhood trends to avoid heavy-handed areas. Safety & Crime at 6/10, Progressivism at 8/10, and Authoritarian Backsliding Risk at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for drug enforcement climate.

Recent history shows sporadic mass violence, so we stay vigilant at large gatherings. Safety & Crime at 6/10 and Stability at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for mass violence incidence.

We track reports to avoid complacency; advocacy groups monitor periodic abuses. Authoritarian Backsliding Risk at 8/10, Safety & Crime at 6/10, and Perceived Corruption at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for carceral conditions & prison labor.

Infrastructure is inconsistent; safe walking requires choosing specific neighborhoods. Public Transportation at 7/10, Housing Situation at 3/10, and Nature Access at 9/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for walkability & pedestrian safety.

We can find wellness support but must seek out likeminded circles to stay motivated. Healthcare (Citizens) at 7/10, Work-Life Balance at 7/10, and Community Vibes at 6/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for community health consciousness.

Maintaining clean eating requires vigilance and possibly specialty stores. Cost of Living (Optional) at 3/10, Community Health Consciousness at 7/10, and Fresh & International Cuisine Access at 7/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for processed food saturation.

We can meet most cravings but specialty ingredients or restaurants appear sporadically. Nightlife & Music at 6/10, Common Hobbies at 8/10, and Meetups & Communities at 8/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for fresh & international cuisine access.

Higher-than-average depression rates prompt us to plan carefully for therapy access. Seasonal Weather at 6/10, Work-Life Balance at 7/10, and Community Vibes at 6/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for depression prevalence.

Higher obesity prevalence indicates limited access to healthy routines in some areas. Community Health Consciousness at 7/10, Work-Life Balance at 7/10, and Cost of Living (Optional) at 3/10 steer the family toward a mixed outlook for obesity rate.

Slightly elevated incidence prompts routine checkups and monitoring. Environment at 8/10, Healthcare (Citizens) at 7/10, and Community Health Consciousness at 7/10 steer the family toward a strong outlook for cancer incidence.
